1_198jKSKMzpRxH5C81bXojho2xGcTxXXcqc.body:
I wholeheartedly agree. It's fast, supports dynamic content, supports anonymity through Tor, and already has lots of great sample apps. This is exactly what I always wanted a decentralized platform to be. It's even better because I never even thought about the idea of being able to clone a site you like with two clicks and make it your own, which makes "installing" a blog or forum software trivially easy. That's a killer feature.

And last but not least, you also don't run into the issue that older decentralized platforms have, where you can't control what content you store and serve to other peers, which used to be among the biggest critiques of decentralized networks. You only serve the sites you visit, so with ZeroNet there are no moral issues in using this software, you don't help distribute illegal content if you don't want to.

I could really see this taking off and becoming huge over the next few years. I'm honestly surprised that it hasn't already gotten much more people interested. Sure, there are still rough edges, but it's already so usable and easy to set up.

> [hotdog](#comment_8_18eNH913qX7e9vBExuMiv7qAMSRkJYNa21): I think it'll get a lot more popular with Tor support

Tor has been supported for months though, ZeroNet already supported Tor when I checked it out for the first time which was late September of last year (just checked my first post here, didn't know I've been using it for so long already). So by now, the people who were waiting for Tor support would have caught up :)

Although the improved Tor support is more recent, as far as I understand it, the only difference is that you can now also publish your own sites via Tor, which you weren't able to do before (I think).

> [nofish](#comment_229_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): Similar: Before full Tor support two Tor peers was unable to communicate to each other, so you was only able to view pages that has non-Tor peers serving the site. It's also faster, more secure (MITM proof) and eliminates NAT drawbacks.

Thanks for the explanation! I didn't notice it being faster, because it was already so fast ;) Even the initial download of sites was really quick for me over Tor, after that it's of course fast because everything is saved locally and only updates are downloaded. But it also feels fast I believe because of all of the nice little animations, distracting from the waiting time :) Really well done.

It is a chicken and egg dilemma in my opinion. Getting people to try out something is relatively easy, especially today where everyone can upload a video explaining a product to the internet and spread it on social media. Getting people to stay however is way harder. The problem is, a really big chunk of people do not come back if they check something out and it isn't working for them yet, if it's boring to them. And on social media, a bad experience can spread fast and wide.

Right now there is very little content, things you can actually spend a lot of time on. I think if people regularly talked here about all kinds of things not just ZeroNet, it would help a lot with this when new people come to check ZeroNet out. The news feeds are a great conversation starter. While this forum specifically might want to stay about ZeroNet only (easier to deal with support that way), another official forum should be made where there are areas for all kind of different topics, gaming, sports, books, movies and TV, etc. And then pull in news feeds from these topics to start conversations, get people to comment on articles.

I think this would help a lot to get things started. And yeah, then get the community together to make a great video that has potential to become viral and post that on Twitter & co (easier said than done of course). Although the right timing is important here. Is ZeroNet already easy enough to install and use for the average joe on Windows right now? I know it isn't on Linux, it was easy for me but I wouldn't trust my parents to be able to do it ;)

> [klauszimmermann](#comment_28_15QGRquMETTn5LnCHjTm1qa9eaXGtq7gpT): You could mention IPFS and it's similarly structured P2P nature for datastore, but ZeroNet is also dynamic, whereas IPFS is almost static.

IPFS does plan to support dynamic websites through IPNS, their nameservice. Basically (as I understand it, so I might be incorrect), you can create a name that points to a resource, lets say the JSON file data.json which is used as a database in ZeroNet. This name (data.json) points to a hash of the data.json file, a version of that file at a specific point in time. This hash will always point to the same file, if it's changed, the hash still points to the old version and a new hash points to the new version, which is why sites in IPFS are static.

To make it dynamic, this same name using IPNS can be used to point to the hash of the new, changed data.json file, so when I request the resource behind the name data.json I will always receive the newest version of the data.json file, with new comments added, new votes, whatever it is that is stored in there.

But I still agree with you that ZeroNet is the most interesting of all of these projects. Like I said earlier in this thread, since IPFS's creators are pro-censorship, it's not everyone's cup of tea. To me it seems like it is mainly targeted at companies who want to save money distributing content rather than creating an internet free of censorship.

ZeroNet is the only option (I know of) if you want both a modern take on decentralization and the freedom to share and debate ideas, and it's IMHO a great option. Really have to applaud ZeroNet's developer here, he is so active. Truly inspiring what he has been able to do in such a relatively short period of time and how much work he puts into both the project itself and answering questions from the community.

Basically, 99.99% of all comedy is forbidden. I don't find that reasonable at all. I like comedy, I enjoy laughing.

But that is besides the point, I am not going to discuss here if Code of Conducts are a good idea. Some people like them, they are free to use them, I have said twice in this thread they are not everyone's cup of tea, my exact words, not that they are devil spawn. I however will not use them, I don't exclude people on such a grand scale. I, and I hope and believe most people, at the very least in western societies, are more tolerant than that.

I will however call it what it is when it's applied to a whole network: Censorship. When you apply this Code of Conduct to a network, a purpose that such a document was never meant for, it is applied to all content shared over that network. We aren't just talking about jokes here anymore, now we are talking about "offensive" pictures, music, movies, books, just everything. Again, this is censorship. And I do not support censorship. Censorship leads to terrible things, it leads to great suffering. I grew up in a country with a long history of censorship that continues to this day and is even getting worse. Censorship is anti intellectual. One of the reasons I am using decentralized networks is to get away from censorship. Did you check out the two tutorials? The second one deals with the database. You can find them in the sidebar of ZeroBlog.

It basically works like o4zw5vmpoz5hz78z says, but the json file every user has is the content.json file. That file tells ZeroNet about all of the user's files, it doesn't hold the actual data from users that gets put into the database, it links to such a data file instead. It's basically the same as the root level content.json file of a ZeroNet site. That file is what gets downloaded by other peers to find out what other files need to be downloaded.

And it also includes information about the user, like his ZeroID. So you don't actually need to save into the database "this post was created by ekaterina@zeroid.bit" because that can just be reconstructed based on the user's content.json file. The second tutorial shows how. The SQL for that looks very complex, that put me off at first, but it's actually easy once you understand all the SQL commands used in the tutorial.

And how the database is constructed from the json data file is something you tell ZeroNet through the use of a dbschema.json file. You tell it how to map nodes in the json to tables in the database. That part is really easy. And ZeroNet then merges all the data from all the users into one database. So if I have a user profile in my json, to use your example, ZeroNet converts this into a single row in the Profiles table (or however you want to call it). Every user's profile becomes a row. That also solves by design the two problems you mentioned, having database entries that anyone can write in and only a certain user can write in.

But yeah since this is decentralized, you need to think a bit differently about things and might have to come up with tricks to solve a problem. You often need a unique ID for table rows for example, like a unique post id so that you can link other table's rows (like comments or votes) to posts, but you can't just create a number on the server that is increased by one every time a new post is created because there is no server, every user is a server. So instead each user gets his own number that is increased by one every time and then you combine that with the user's identity address (which is also the name of the user's data folder) to make that id unique. For example, let's say my identity address is md393939dmmf39. If I create a new post, it's unique ID would become 1-md393939dmmf39. My second post would be 2-md393939dmmf39, and so on. Other users will use the same numbers starting from one, but there identity address will be different, that one is unique. Check out the source of ZeroTalk, ZeroBlog and so on on Github, it's quite easy to follow and it'll teach you all of that.

1_1BDTDgpyizvUDsc1hcL1pjCvXCy4ozzSFN.body: Everyone who uses ZeroMail gets a copy, encrypted of course so only you and the mail's recipient can read it. It uses ECIES (Elliptic Curve Integrated Encryption Scheme) and AES encryption. You send the mail by creating a file (a JSON file with the encrypted data) on your harddrive, and then telling other ZeroMail users "hey, here's a new file, download it". In the case that nobody else who uses ZeroMail should be online at the moment (which never happens, has lots of users), the mail would be sent to other peers as soon as you and someone else is online, until then it stays on your harddrive until you delete ZeroMail, so it will never get lost unless you delete it and nobody else already downloaded it from you. And the recipient can then download the mail from any ZeroMail user who is online when he is.

It **is** recommended to use the ZeroNet client through Tor and the ZeroNet sites through TorBrowser if you want privacy, so in effect you will be running Tor twice, once for ZeroNet and once for the browser. This way, if a ZeroNet site you visit requests a resource from the normal internet outside of ZeroNet (because the site creator didn't know any better or is malicious), your IP isn't leaked. Unless you use a VPN that masks your whole internet traffic, then of course your VPN provider's IP would be leaked, not your own.

It is also possible to run your browser in a virtual machine without internet access while you have the ZeroNet client running on your host OS with internet access. That is probably the most secure, even potential security exploits can't cause any harm then since there is no internet, only the ZeroNet API that can talk to the Host OS to download/upload using ZeroNet only. It's always a tradeoff between convenience and security, you need to decide for yourself how big your threat model is so how elaborate your security needs to be, I'm sure there are even more insane lengths you can go to to make it even more secure :)

If you do decide to use Tor Browser (I started out using Chrome and then switched myself), you need to configure it once to allow direct access to your local host to make it work with ZeroNet. Preferences/Advanced/Network/Connection/Settings/No Proxy for -> enter 127.0.0.1

When you write a comment or vote on something, that information is written to a text file called data.json by the website. Every user of a ZeroNet site has a content.json file which other peers download, in that content.json is a link to all files a user created including that data.json file with your comments (and for other sites there might also be pictures, or additional JSON files, etc). Other peers then download this data.json file they found in content.json to get your comments and votes. ZeroNet can automatically create an SQLite database from all those different users' data.json files to turn everything into one big SQL database with all comments from all users, for display on the site.

You can also listen for certain events, like when your ZeroNet client just downloaded a new data.json file you can make your site update in real time with the new content, without the user having to reload. It's all extremely easy for the programmer, ZeroNet takes care of the actual work.

Try opening this folder: YourZeroNetFolder/data/1BLogC9LN4oPDcruNz3qo1ysa133E9AGg8/data/users/ and go into one of the folders there and open a data.json file with a text editor to see how this looks for ZeroBlog.

For more technical details, check out the two part site development tutorial on ZeroBlog which teaches you to create a chat application, works the same as comments and votes do.

> [ax](#comment_6_1LnYjFf7ZGJGmyUhd6pyG5GQYDrPBNVkCX): I really would like to know the answers to these questions that still haven't been answered so I'll repost in the hope erkan, nofish or someone else of equal skill level can answer.
> How exactly does ZeroID go 'outside', what ip addresses, services etc does it force users to connect to? Exactly what info are users forced to leak?
> Precisely which sql commands can be be used to create a profile of users and exactly what info can be extrapolated?
> 'Powerful admins' could potentially be a problem, therefore designing a 'trustless' system should be the priority rather than just reinventing the wheel and creating even more all powerful admins that may not be entirely trustworthy.

A ZeroNet site cannot be censored by a third party, you can create a blog and write whatever you please, no company and no government can bring your blog down. However, the owner of a site can do whatever he wants. That means the owner of a site can censor. That means the owner can send information outside of ZeroNet to the clearnet, and yes ZeroID right now doesn't work without doing that, the Source Code for all official ZeroNet sites is open source, including ZeroID, take a look to see exactly what it does: https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroID

To find out more how ZeroNet sites in general work I'd also recommend going through the ZeroNet site development tutorial part 1 and 2 that are linked on the official ZeroBlog in the sidebar. Then you understand why things work the way they do. If you are not a developer and can't go through the source yourself, I can only say there is nothing nefarious going on as far as I can see, there are technical reasons behind this.

Username registration (ZeroID), domain registration (ZeroName) and things like it where you need some kind of ledger were traditionally something where you needed a central service, otherwise everyone could register the same username or steal someone's username. ZeroID connects to an open source PHP script on a server to handle this if I am not mistaken (while I've read a lot of the official ZeroNet sites' source code, ZeroID I have looked at the least).

There are now decentralized alternatives to deal with this issue, some already usable others still in development, you can use the Bitcoin blockchain technology for example, that's what Namecoin does for domain registration, you can use Ethereum which is being specifically created to add this (and other types of smart contracts as they are called) functionality on top of other decentralized networks like ZeroNet.

However, blockchain systems have a huge drawback. Blockchains don't scale. They just don't. Ethereum's takes a day to download already and it's not even released yet, it's still in development, it's all in a beta/alpha state. Namecoin also takes 20 hours or so depending on the speed of your harddrive among others. If ZeroNet were to use a blockchain, surely nobody would use it but for a very small niche of people, it would never grow, you can't make the mainstream wait a day (and as time passes days, then weeks and so on) before they can ever open and use their first website. But if you still want to, you can use blockchains with ZeroNet. ZeroName for example, that is also a centralized service by default (doesn't connect to the clearnet though I believe). But there is a plugin you can enable for ZeroNet (look in your ZeroNet Plugins folder) to use your own Namecoin node which has downloaded the huge Namecoin blockchain so you don't need to rely on / trust the ZeroName site, it's just the default because blockchains are huge and it makes everything so much harder. Maybe something like that will be possible for ZeroID too. If not, you have the option to use a different ID provider like ZeroVerse and hopefully soon even more as more people create their own to make this less centralized.

As for the censorship, yes, that is not optimal, that is something I still don't like 100% either. But there is no right answer here, there are always up and downsides to every solution. ZeroNet's idea of stopping censorship by site owners is giving people the ability to clone sites if a site admin misbehaves. Not all sites are cloneable, the site owner decides if you can clone it, but users should therefore prefer to use sites that are cloneable if they don't want to get locked in to a site that could end up censoring.

Also please keep in mind ZeroNet is version 0.36. The project is only a little over a year old and made by one person. Don't expect a perfect system this early in the life of the project. It is improving all the time and I'm sure these things will also be improved if they can be improved without sacrificing too much (like a blockchain would).

Oh and about the ZeroPolls SQL query, since I created ZeroPolls, just look at the ZeroPolls.coffee source code in your ZeroNet folder, I distribute it with all my sites. The SQL query I use actually does fetch the usernames, it just doesn't display them. There is nothing that can be done about this, this is just how ZeroNet sites work since they are decentralized, every user has all the data, there is no hidden data. So Erkan's ZeroVerse and making a throwaway account solves this issue, votes are tied to your id and someone could find out what that ID voted on, but if you use ZeroVerse as a throwaway id you don't need to care about that.
